projects.graph

Class SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.graph.Graph
      • projects.graph.SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

  • public class SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph
extends Graph

    SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph is a Graph implemented as a sparse adjacency matrix, i.e a linked list of the matrix's non-null (or, in this case, non-zero) elements.

    Inserting a new node has no influence in the inner storage of this class, because the only storage it provides is for edges. This does not mean that you should neglect to store information about a new node having been inserted: it just means that a new node needs to be connected to an existing one if it is to appear as a new node in the list. Think about the (dense) adjacency matrix representation: there, if we add a new node, we have to pay O(V^2) to re-allocate the space of the old array to the new array and add a new row and column of zeroes. There is no novel assignment in the matrix! In the case of the sparsified representation, the inner representation does not have to change at all! But you will still need to make note of the fact that a new node was inserted. After all, we want getNumNodes() to work correctly, don't we?

    Adding a new edge is also O(1), because there's no need to keep the list ordered; we can just add the element in the front without any further hassle. If you are having trouble understanding why the list can be unordered, check the docs of toAdjacencyMatrixGraph().

    edgeBetween(int, int), deleteEdge(int, int), getEdgeWeight(int, int) and getNeighbors(int) all run in O(E) time.

    The space occupied by an instance of SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph is O(E).

    See Also:
    Graph, AdjacencyMatrixGraph, AdjacencyListGraph

    • Method Detail

      • addNode

        public void addNode()
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Add a new node to the graph. The node will be characterized by its index of insertion, such that the first time this method is called, a node with index ' 0 ' is stored in the graph, the second one we will store a node with index ' 1 ', etc, etc.

        Specified by:
        addNode in class Graph

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge(int source,
                    int dest,
                    int weight)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Adds an edge from node source to node dest in the graph, attaching to it weight equal to weight. In this implementation, we don't allow weights to be negative. If a weight that is either negative or greater than Graph.INFINITY is provided, the method should throw a RuntimeException. If the edge already exists, its weight should be updated to the parameter value.

        If either source or dest don't exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined. This means that you can do whatever you want, as long as you don't store extra edges or nodes in the graph. You can throw a RuntimeException, return null, print a message, anything. We do not test for this case.

        We treat the addition of a weight with zero weight exactly the same way we would treat the deletion of an edge through Graph.deleteEdge(int, int). So, the calls add(i, j, 0) and deleteEdge(i, j) are equivalent.

        Specified by:
        addEdge in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.
        weight - The weight of the edge.

      • deleteEdge

        public void deleteEdge(int source,
                       int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Delete the edge from source to dest. If the edge does not exist, or if either node does not exist in the graph, no action should be performed.

        We would like to particularly stress that removing an edge does not in any way imply removing its constituent nodes, even if the nodes end up being singleton disconnected components!

        Specified by:
        deleteEdge in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The "source" node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.

      • edgeBetween

        public boolean edgeBetween(int source,
                           int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Queries the graph about the existence of an edge from source to dest. If either source or dest are not contained by the graph, then the edge itself cannot possibly exist and the method should return false.

        Specified by:
        edgeBetween in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, source, dest and the edge source->dest all exist in the graph, false otherwise.

      • getEdgeWeight

        public int getEdgeWeight(int source,
                         int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Returns the weight of the edge source->dest. If the edge does not exist (either because at least one of the two nodes does not exist or because they both exist but there is no edge between them), this method should return 0.

        Specified by:
        getEdgeWeight in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        the weight of the edge source->dest

      • getNeighbors

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> getNeighbors(int node)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Retrieves the "neighbor" nodes of the provided node, i.e all the nodes to which it points. If the node does not exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined; you can do whatever you want (and that helps you debug!) and we don't test for it. If the node does exist in the graph but it has no neighbors, the returned Set should be non-null, but empty (size 0).

        Specified by:
        getNeighbors in class Graph
        Parameters:
        node - The node to retrieve the neighbors of.
        Returns:
        A Set of all nodes to which node is incident (whether it is the source OR sink).

      • toAdjacencyMatrixGraph

        public AdjacencyMatrixGraph toAdjacencyMatrixGraph()
        Creates the dense representation of the matrix, corresponding to an instance of AdjacencyMatrixGraph. The adjacency matrix will occupy O(V^2) space. Since every node in the list that makes up the sparsified representation containsKVPair a triple (i, j, weight), simply looping through the list in O(E) and assigning the corresponding cell of the matrix to the appropriate weight is sufficient. For this reason, it is not important whether the list is sorted in any way, except for the special case of having been immediately created by AdjacencyMatrixGraph.toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph(), where we want you to create the adjacency list following row-major order. However, because of this simple iterative algorithm we just explained, addEdge() in this class is an O(1) operation: we can just insert a new node as the "head" of the list, and we are done. You are not allowed to implement this method by using other transformation methods. For example, you cannot implement it with the line of code toAdjacencyListGraph().toAdjacencyMatrixGraph().
        Returns:
        An AdjacencyMatrixGraph instance.

      • toAdjacencyListGraph

        public AdjacencyListGraph toAdjacencyListGraph()
        Transforms this to an AdjacencyListGraphinstance. Remember that an AdjacencyListGraph is implemented as an array of linked lists, where A(i) is a linked list containing the neighbors of node i. You are not allowed to implement this method by using other transformation methods. For example, you cannot implement it with the line of code toAdjacencyMatixGraph().toAdjacencyListGraph().
        Returns:
        An AdjacencyListGraph instance.
